TITLE I--EXTENSION OF PERIOD FOR REIMBURSEMENT UNDER FISHERMEN'S PROTECTIVE ACT OF 1967

This title may be cited as the "Fishermen's Protective Act Amendments of 2000". Section 7(e) of the Fishermen's Protective Act of 1967 is amended to extend the period for reimbursement from 2000 to 2003. Additionally, a clerical amendment changes the reference from the Secretary of the Interior to the Secretary of Commerce.

TITLE II--YUKON RIVER SALMON

This title may be cited as the "Yukon River Salmon Act of 2000". It establishes the Yukon River Salmon Panel. The Yukon River Salmon Panel, established under the Yukon River Salmon Act of 2000, advises on international agreements with Canada, restoration of salmon stocks, and other conservation functions authorized by law. The Panel may also serve as US representatives on future bilateral bodies related to salmon conservation. The Yukon River Salmon Panel, established under the Yukon River Salmon Act of 2000, consists of six members with expertise in salmon conservation and management, appointed by the United States and Alaska governments. The Yukon River Salmon Panel, established under the Yukon River Salmon Act of 2000, consists of six members appointed by the Secretary of State in accordance with nominations from the Governor of Alaska to represent various fishing districts. The Yukon River Salmon Panel consists of six members appointed by the Secretary of State, including a member representing Upper Yukon River fishing districts and at least one Alaska Native. Alternate members may be designated to serve in the absence of appointed members, all serving 4-year terms. The Yukon River Salmon Panel members can be reappointed and make decisions by consensus. They may consult with other parties as needed. The Governor of Alaska may establish an advisory committee of 8-12 individuals knowledgeable about Yukon River salmon fisheries, including at least two Alaska Natives. Committee members can attend Panel meetings, voice opinions, and serve 2-year terms without compensation. Reappointment is possible. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Panel or any advisory committee established under section 203. The Panel has authority and responsibility. The State of Alaska Department of Fish and Game is designated as the responsible management entity for salmon stocks from the Yukon River in Canada. This designation does not change the management authority of the State or Federal Government. The Panel may make recommendations on salmon conservation to the Department of the Interior. The Panel may make advisory recommendations on salmon conservation originating in the Yukon River to various Federal and State entities. SEC. 206. ADMINISTRATIVE MATTERS. Panel members and alternate Panel members who are not State or Federal employees shall receive compensation at the daily rate of GS-15 of the General Schedule when engaged in the actual performance of duties. Travel and other necessary expenses will be paid by the Secretary of the Interior for all Panel members, alternate Panel members, and members of any advisory committee when engaged in the actual performance of duties. They are not considered Federal employees except for injury compensation or tort claims liability. Panel members and alternate Panel members who are not State or Federal employees shall receive compensation at the daily rate of GS-15 of the General Schedule when engaged in the actual performance of duties. They are not considered Federal employees except for injury compensation or tort claims liability. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, may carry out projects to restore or enhance salmon stocks from the Yukon River in Canada and the United States. Projects must comply with any existing agreement between the US and Canada for the conservation of Yukon River salmon stocks, including funding provisions. SEC. 208. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary of the Interior to carry out specific activities related to the Pacific Salmon Treaty between the United States and Canada, including travel expenses for panel members and advisory committee members. The United States will share expenses with Canada for salmon restoration and enhancement. Up to $3,000,000 annually will be allocated for survey, restoration, and enhancement activities for Yukon River salmon stocks. Additionally, $600,000 will be available each year for cooperative salmon research and management projects in the Yukon River drainage in the United States as recommended by the Panel. TITLE III--FISHERY INFORMATION ACQUISITION

This title is known as the "Fisheries Survey Vessel Authorization Act of 2000". It involves the acquisition of fishery survey vessels. The Secretary may acquire and equip up to six fishery survey vessels capable of staying at sea for 30 days, conducting fishery population surveys, and meeting acoustic quietness standards. Authorization is given to the Secretary to appropriate $60,000,000 for fiscal years 2002 and 2003 to carry out the exploration of the Sea standard regarding acoustic quietness. TITLE IV--MISCELLANEOUS

SEC. 401. FISHERIES RESEARCH VESSEL PROCUREMENT.

The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to procure Fisheries Research Vessels through full and open competition from responsible United States shipbuilding companies, regardless of size.
